title: Protocol for identifying physiologically relevant binding proteins of G-protein-coupled receptors
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell culture and transfection
Timing: 2 weeks
In this step, WT GPR110 or F663S mutant is transiently expressed in HEK293 cells.
We recommend performing two experiments on three biological replicates. The first experiment aims to filter out the background proteins by identifying the common binding proteins of the expressed GPR110 and M45 control. The second experiment is to identify physiologically relevant partners by comparing the data from the WT GPR110 with the F663S mutant. Six 15-cm dishes of cells are required for each experiment.
Cell culture.
Culture and maintain HEK293 cells in 15-cm dishes in EMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) at 37°C in a humidified CO2 (5%) incubator.
Critical: Cells with passage numbers of 8–12 are used for transfection.
Cell transfection.
Seed HEK293 cells.
Seed HEK293 cells (∼8 × 106 cells) in 15-cm dishes and incubate the cells at 37°C in a CO2 incubator for 16–20 h.
Note: Cell density should be 60%–80% confluent at the time of transfection.
Transfect HEK293 cells.
Note: The following protocol is used for transfection of a 15-cm dish of cells. The regents should be scaled up for triplicate samples.
Dilute 5 μg of GPR110, or F663S, or M45 plasmid in 700 μL of Opti-MEM I.
Reduced Serum Media (Opti-MEM).
Dilute 50 μL Lipofectamine 2000 in 700 μL of Opti-MEM.
Mix solutions from Steps i and ii and incubate for 15 min at room temperature (25°C).
Add the mixed solution to the 15-cm dish of cells from Step a drop by stop using a pipette. Gently rock the dish back and forth.
Incubate the cells at 37°C and under 5% CO2 for 24 h.
In-cell crosslinking
Timing: 1 h
In this step, protein-protein interactions are captured in living cells by chemical crosslinking with DSS.

In-cell crosslinking with DSS.
Replace the medium with PBS.
Remove and discard the medium by aspiration.
Wash cells with 10 mL PBS.
Note: Gently add 10 mL PBS to the side of the dish to avoid disturbing the cell layer, and gently rock the dish back and forth 3–5 times. Also, aspiration should be performed gently.
Remove and discard the PBS by aspiration.
Add 5 mL PBS.
Critical: Crosslinking cannot be performed in buffers containing primary amines.
Crosslink proteins with DSS.
Prepare freshly 200 mM DSS in DMSO.
Add 25 μL of 200 mM DSS to cells in PBS (Step 3iv). Gently rock the dish back and forth 3–5 times. Incubate for 30 min at room temperature (25°C).
Quench crosslinking.
Add 150 μL of 1M Tris-HCl buffer (pH = 7.4) to quench the crosslinking reaction. Mix gently by rocking the dish back and forth several times. Incubate for 10 min at room temperature.
Note: It is normal that some cells become floating after crosslinking.
Immunoprecipitation (IP)
Timing: 2 days
In this step, cells are lysed and the HA-tagged GPR110 and its interacting proteins are pulled down by HA-antibody conjugated to protein G beads. The immunoprecipitated proteins are eluted from the beads by HA peptide.
Preparation of cell lysate.
Harvest cells.
Detach the cells without removing PBS using a cell lifter.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 15-mL conical tube.
Centrifuge the sample for 5 min at 4°C at 1,000 × g.
Discard the supernatant by aspiration.
Note: Care should be taken not to disturb the cell pellet.
Critical: Do not directly remove PBS from the culture dishes which will result in loss of the floating cells. Do not harvest the cells by trypsin digestion, as trypsin digestion accelerates the degradation of proteins in the lysate.
Lyse cells.

Add 1.5 mL cold lysis buffer to the pellet. Resuspend the pellet by pipetting up and down 3–5 times.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 1.5 Eppendorf tube.
Incubate the cell suspension on ice for 30 min. Vortex for 1–2 s every 5 min.
Centrifuge the cells for 15 min at 4°C at 15,000 × g.
Collect and transfer the supernatant to a new Eppendorf tube. Keep samples on ice.
Determine the protein concentration using BCA Protein Assay kit. Adjust the protein concentration to the lowest sample concentration with lysis buffer if necessary.
Note: We use 1.3 mL (∼3.5 mg proteins) of the lysate for each IP. Additionally, 20 μL of each sample is used for western blotting with HA antibody to confirm the expression level of total GPR110 and F663S.
Immunoprecipitation with HA antibody.
Incubate the lysate with HA antibody.
Transfer 1.3 mL of the lysate (Step 4bv) for each sample to an Eppendorf tube.
Add 40 μL of HA antibody to the lysate. Incubate samples on a rotator overnight (16–20 h) at 4°C.
Prepare protein G beads.
Add 40 μL of well-resuspended magnetic Dynabeads Protein G to a 1.5-mL Eppendorf tube.
Place the tube in the rack of DynaMag-2 magnet for 1 min. Remove and discard the supernatant.
Note: Remove the supernatant with a pipette while the tube is in the magnet rack. Care should be taken not to disturb the accumulated beads.
Conjugate antibody to protein G beads.
Transfer the HA antibody-incubated lysate (from Step 5aii) to the tube containing the Dynabeads Protein G (Step 5bii).
Incubate for 4 h at 4°C on a rotator.
Wash non-specifically bound proteins.
Place samples in the rack of DynaMag-2 magnet for 1 min. Remove and discard the supernatant.

Remove the tubes from the magnet. Wash beads by adding 800 μL of lysis buffer.
Gently shake the tubes by hand. Spin down the beads briefly using a low-speed microcentrifuge.
Place the tubes on the magnet for 1 min. Remove and discard the supernatant.
Repeat Steps ii and iii two more times.
Note: Remove the supernatant with a pipette while the tubes are in the magnet rack. Care should be taken not to disturb the accumulated beads.
Elute co-immunoprecipitated proteins.
Prepare 1 mg/mL HA peptide in lysis buffer.
Add 50 μL of 1 mg/mL HA peptide to each tube from Step 5div.
Place the samples on a rotisserie rotator for 20 min at 30°C.
Place the samples on DynaMag-2 magnet for 1 min.
Collect and transfer the supernatant to a new Eppendorf tube.
Pause point: The samples containing co-immunoprecipitated proteins can be stored at ‒80°C until further use.
In-gel digestion
Timing: 3 days
In this step, GPR110 and its interacting protein partners are separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate poly-acrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and digested by trypsin.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3098-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Gel fractionation for in-gel digestion, LC-MS/MS and label-free quantitation
Gel bands are cut out into fractions (i.e., fraction A-C) from each sample (i.e., sample number 1–6) according to the molecular weight range of interest.
In-gel digestion.
Separate proteins with SDS-PAGE.
Mix 40 μL of the protein solution eluted from Step 5ev with 13.3 μL 4x lithium dodecyl sulfate (LDS) sample buffer containing 5% β-mercaptoethanol.
Incubate the samples at 37°C for 30 min.
Assemble a XCell SureLock Mini-Cell system with NuPAGE 4%–12% Bis-Tris mini gel (1.0 mm × 10 well) and MOPS SDS running buffer.
Load 45 μL of each sample. Load 5 μL protein standards before the 1st sample and after the last sample.

Start electrophoresis with a constant voltage of 200 V. Stop when the dye front is around 1 cm away from the base of the gel.
Note: The electrophoresis time is about 60 min.
Stain gel with Coomassie G-250.
Remove the gel and wash the gel with 100 mL ultrapure water (18.2MΩ-cm) three times for 5 min. Discard each rinse.
Stain the gel with 20 mL of SimplyBlue SafeStain (Coomassie G-250) for 1 h at room temperature (25°C).
Remove and discard the staining solution.
Incubate the gel in 100 mL of ultrapure water for 1 h.
Cut out and excise gel bands.
Critical: Wear gloves, sleeve protectors, mask, and cap to avoid keratin contamination. Clean gel cutting tools (blades and forceps) subsequently with methanol and water. Clean workspace (glass plates and bench). Do not talk over samples.
Place gel on a clean glass plate. Cut out gel bands using a wide stainless steel surgical prep blade.
Note: In the case of GPR110, the monomeric receptor band appears at ∼130 kDa. Bands above ∼130 kDa are expected to contain interacting partners that are crosslinked to GPR110 via DSS. To identify more proteins, we divided the gel slice above 100 kDa into three fractions, 100–150 kDa, 150–250 kDa and 250 kDa to the top of the gel (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Dice the gel slice of each lane (i.e., each sample) into 1 × 1 mm pieces using a single edge razor blade. Collect the gel pieces into a 1.5-mL Eppendorf tube containing 200 μL water using filter forceps.
Note: Water in the collecting tube helps separate gel slices from the forceps.
Remove and discard water from the tube using a gel loading tip.
De-stain gel pieces.

Add 200 μL (or enough to cover) of de-staining solution (25 mM NH4HCO3 in 50% ACN). Vortex and spin briefly with a low-speed microcentrifuge. Incubate samples in a shaker for 30 min at room temperature (25°C).
Remove and discard the supernatant using a gel loading tip.
Repeat Steps i-ii.
Add 50 μL 100% ACN to dehydrate the gel pieces. Vortex and spin briefly. Incubate on a shaker for 5 min. Discard the supernatant.
Note: Gel pieces become white and semi-opaque after this step.
Reduce and alkylate proteins.
Dry the gel pieces completely with a vacuum concentrator (typically 30 min at 25°C).
Add 100 μL (or enough to cover) of 10 mM DTT freshly made in 25 mM NH4HCO3 to the dried gel pieces. Vortex and spin briefly. Incubate the samples at 56°C for 1 h.
Add 100 μL 110 mM iodoacetamide freshly made in 25 mM NH4HCO3. Vortex and spin briefly.
Incubate at room temperature (25°C) for 45 min in the dark (e.g., cover the tubes and the rack with aluminum foil and place them in a drawer).
Remove and discard supernatant.
Add 200 μL of 25 mM NH4HCO3. Vortex and spin briefly. Incubated on a shaker for 10 min.vi. Remove and discard supernatant.
Add 200 μL 25 mM NH4HCO3 in 50% ACN. Incubated on a shaker for 10 min.
Remove and discard supernatant.
Repeat Steps vi-vii.
Add 50 μL 100% ACN to dehydrate the gel pieces. Vortex and spin briefly. Incubate on a shaker for 5 min. Discard the supernatant.
Note: After adding ACN, the gel pieces turn white and semi-opaque.
Dry the gel pieces completely with a vacuum concentrator (typically 30 min at 25°C).
Pause point: The gel pieces are now ready for digestion. However, they can be stored at ‒80°C for up to several weeks.

Digest proteins in-gel.
Prepare freshly 12.5 ng/μL trypsin/Lys-C in 25 mM NH4HCO3.
Critical: Ensure that the trypsin/Lys-C pellet is at the bottom of the vial before adding 25 mM NH4HCO3. Gently tap down the pellet that sticks to the cap if necessary.
Add 100 μL of 12.5 ng/μL trypsin to dried gel pieces. Incubate on ice for 30 min to allow absorption of the solution into the gel.
Note: To ensure gel pieces are fully submerged, the volume of trypsin solution should be at least three times as that of the dried gel pieces. If necessary, more trypsin solution can be added to completely cover the gel pieces.
Incubate the samples at 37°C in an incubator for 16–20 h.
Extract peptides.
Prepare peptide extraction solution (PXS). Mix 5% formic acid in water with ACN at 1:1 ratio.
Add 100 μL of PXS (or the volume of the trypsin/Lys-C solution added in Step 6 fii). Vortex and spin briefly. Incubate in a shaker for 10 min at room temperature.
Collect and transfer the supernatant to a new tube.
Add 100 μL of PXS to the gel pieces. Vortex and spin briefly. Incubate in a shaker for 10 min at room temperature.
Collect and pool the supernatant to the same tube in step iii.
Repeat iv and v.
Dry the pooled supernatant containing tryptic peptides with a vacuum concentrator (typically 2–3 h at 25°C).
Pause point: The dried peptide samples can be stored at ‒80°C freezer until further use.
Liquid chromatography/high resolution mass-spectrometry
Timing: 3 days
In this step, peptides are purified and subjected to LC-MS/MS analysis.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3098_16.csv
A: 99.9% H2O, 0.1% formic acid; B: 97.9% ACN, 2% H2O, 0.1% formic acid.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3098_17.csv
Prepare peptides for LC-MS/MS analysis.
Desalt peptides.

Dissolve the dried peptides by adding 10 μL of 0.1% TFA. Vortex and spin briefly.
Note: Check the pH of the peptide solution using a pH paper. We perform this by pipetting a minimal amount of the solution (0.07 μL with a 2.5 μL pipette) into a strip of pH paper. Typically, the pH value is around 2–3.
Critical: The pH should be less than 4 before the desalting step described below. Otherwise, the binding of peptides to C18 ZipTip column is compromised, and peptides are lost during washing steps.
Remove salts and contaminants using Millipore C18 ZipTip according to manufacturer’s instructions. In this step, the purified peptides are eluted with 10 μL 0.1% TFA in 50% ACN.
Note: We use 10 μL Millipore ZipTip pipette tips with 0.6 μL C18 resin. The binding capacity of the ZipTip is 3 μg peptides. Adjust the amounts of peptides to be desalted if necessary.
Dry the purified peptides to dryness with a vacuum concentrator (typically 30 min at 25°C).
Pause point: At this point, dried desalted peptides can be stored at ‒80°C until further use.
Note: Alternatively, dry the sample down to 5 μL to remove ACN. The sample is ready for LC-MS/MS analysis (Step 8b).
LC-MS/MS.
This section describes LC-MS/MS procedures for analyzing peptides on an Orbitrap Fusion Lumos Tribrid Mass Spectrometer equipped with an Ultimate 3000 RSLCnano system (Thermo Scientific). Alternatively, mass spectrometers and liquid chromatography systems from other manufacturers can be used for analysis of the samples.
Reconstitute peptide samples.
Add 5 μL of 0.1% TFA to each dried desalted peptide sample. Vortex for 10 s. Spin down briefly with a microcentrifuge.
Transfer the samples into vials compatible with the autosampler of the liquid chromatography system.

Note: We use 2 mL glass vials with a 250 μL polypropylene conical insert with flexible feet and PTFE cap.
Place samples in the autosampler of the liquid chromatography system.
Critical: To ensure longer shelf life of the peptide samples, it is important to set the temperature of the autosampler at 4°C.
Set up sequence for LC-MS/MS runs.
Select LC-MS/MS method, injection volume (e.g., 2 μL), vial position, etc.
Run sequence.
Note: During LC-MS/MS, peptides are injected onto a C18 peptide trap column and washed with 25 μL of trap column LC solvent at a rate of 5 μL/min for 5 min. The peptides are then eluted from the trap column into an analytical column and separated with 120-min gradients of nano-LC Mobile Phase B at a rate of 300 nL/min. The nano-LC eluent is analyzed by high resolution mass spectrometry in full scan mode and MS/MS in data-dependent acquisition mode (DDA). A recommended mobile phase gradient and mass spectrometry method are suggested in Tables 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] and 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2], respectively.
Protein identification
Timing: 2 days
In this step, proteins are identified by searching of MS/MS data against NCBInr database. Potential interacting proteins of GPR110 are identified by comparing the binding proteins of GPR110 with the M45 control.
Identify potential interacting proteins.
Process batches of raw files for GPR110- and M45-transfected samples using Mascot (v2.3.2, Matrix Science).
Note: Other search engines such as Proteome Discovery represent valid options for the analysis.
Import the raw data files into Mascot Daemon using Mascot Distiller as the data import filter.
Search for protein identification using Mascot against the NCBInr database.

Note: Search parameters are set as follows: enzyme, trypsin; precursor ion mass tolerance, 10 ppm; fragment ion mass tolerance, 0.3 Da; maximum missed cleavages allowed 2; carbamidomethyl of cysteine residues for fixed modification; oxidation of methionine and addition of 156. 07864 Da on lysine or N-terminal (end-capping modification) for variable modification. The criteria used to filter results included 1% false positive threshold and expect value of less than 0.05 for significant peptide matches. The expect score was calculated using the homology threshold or the significance threshold as per a standard Mascot protein family report.
Export the search results to Excel files.
Compare proteins identified from GPR110-transfected samples with those from M45 controls.
Identify potential interacting proteins of GPR110.
Exclude non-specific binding proteins that are found in M45 samples.
Exclude proteins that are not reproducible in three independent experiments.
Label-free protein quantification
Timing: 2 days
In this step, physiologically relevant partners of GPR110 are identified by quantitatively comparing the binding proteins of WT GPR110 with F663S mutant. We describe here a label-free quantitation procedure using Progenesis QI for Proteomics (version 1.05156.29278, Waters). Alternative softwares from other sources such as MaxQuant5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5] may also provide valid options for quantitative analysis of proteins.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3098-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Alignment for accurate label-free protein quantitation
An example is shown for fraction C of 6 individual samples. Progenesis QI for proteomics software aligns six LC-MS/MS data to compensate for between-run variation in the LC separation technique, resulting in increased reliability and precision of peak picking and peptide abundance measurements. An alignment vector is a representation of the difference between the chromatographic retention times of an ion in one run and the equivalent ion in the reference run. The quality of the alignment is indicated by the scores.
Identify physiologically relevant partners by label-free protein quantitation.

Open Progenesis QI for Proteomics.
Create a “LC-MS Experiment” for a gel fraction (e.g., Fraction A, B or C as in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Name “Experiment” (e.g., Fraction A).
Select “Profile data” as Data type.
Select “High resolution mass spectrometer” as Machine type.
Select Experiment folder.
Click on “Create experiment”.
Import data.
Import raw mass spectrometric files of the fraction (e.g., A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, and A6 in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Start automatic processing.
Select “Assess all runs in the experiment for suitability” in “Select an alignment reference” box.
Select “yes” in “Automatic alignment” box.
Select “perform peak picking” in “Peak picking” box.
Select “Relative Quantitation using non-conflicting peptides” in “Protein Quantitation” box.
Review alignment (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Critical: Review the alignment result. Alignment makes it possible to accurately compare the peptides in multiple runs by correcting any drift in retention times.
Process “Filtering”.
Exclude features with charge of 1 and charge > 7 for the analysis.
Set up experiment design.
Create new experiment design (e.g., WT vs. KO).
Set up conditions (e.g., group A1, A2 and A3 as “WT” and group A4, A5 and A6 as “KO”).
Identify peptides.
Select “Export as mgf file” under the “Identify peptides” window.
Search for protein identification using Mascot (v2.3.2, Matrix Science) against the NCBInr human database as described in Step 9aii.
Export Mascot results to xml files.
Import the xml result files under the “Identify peptides” window.
Save the processed data for the “Experiment” (e.g., Fraction A).
Repeat Steps 10a-10i for each fraction (e.g., Fractions B and C).
Combine processed data.
Import processed Experiments for each fraction (e.g., Fractions A, B and C).
Recombine processed Experiments for all fractions from each sample. Combine runs from each fraction from the same sample (e.g., combine A1, B1 and C1 for sample 1 (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2])).

Note: Normalization between fractions is performed during this step.
Setup experimental design (e.g., WT vs. F663S).
Export protein quantitation data to Excel.
Analyze data.
Obtain the ratio of binding protein over GPR110 for WT GPR110- and F663S-transfected samples, for each or selected potential interacting protein identified from Step 9.
Calculate p value using Student’s test.
Identify physiologically relevant partners.
The proteins that show significant reduction in the F663S sample are deemed as physiologically relevant partners of GPR110.
Validation of functional binding partners
Timing: 3 days
In this section, we describe the validation of occludin, a GPR110 partner identified from the MS-based approach described above (Step 10 m), as an example. Reciprocal immunoprecipitation assay, the gold standard for the validation of protein-protein interactions, is used to confirm the interaction of occludin with GPR110. Notably, not only the interaction with WT GPR110 but also the reduced interaction with the F663S mutant are considered the validation criteria in this antibody-based technique.
Validate occludin as GPR110 interacting partner by reciprocal co-immunoprecipitation assay.
Prepare cell lysate.
Culture and transfect HEK293 cells with WT GPR110, F663S mutant, or empty vector M45 as described in Steps 1–2.
Remove and discard medium after 24 h transfection.
Add 10 mL PBS. Gently rock the culture dish back and forth. Remove and discard PBS.
Repeat Step iii.
Add 1.5 mL lysis buffer to the cells. Scrape with a cell lifter. Transfer the cell suspension into an Eppendorf tube.
Prepare the lysate as described in Steps 4biii-v.
Prepare pre-IP lysate samples.
Take 60 μL of each lysate, add 20 μL 4x lithium dodecyl sulfate (LDS) sample buffer containing 5% β-mercaptoethanol. Vortex and spin.
Incubate the samples at 37°C for 30 min.
Note: These samples are to be used for normalization in reciprocal western blot analysis.
Perform reciprocal co-immunoprecipitation.

Split 1.3 mL of each lysate into two Eppendorf tubes.
To each tube, add 20 μL HA antibody or 20 μL occlduin antibody.
Proceed immunoprecipitation procedure as described in Steps 5b-5d.
Elute the co-immunoprecipitated proteins.
Add 40 μL 2x lithium dodecyl sulfate (LDS) sample buffer containing 2.5%
β-mercaptoethanol.
Incubate the samples at 37°C for 30 min.
Place tubes in the rack of DynaMag-2 magnet for 1 min.
Collect and transfer the supernatant to a new Eppendorf tube. The samples are ready for western blotting described below.
Pause point: Samples can be stored in ‒80°C for up to several weeks.
Separate proteins using SDS-PAGE.
We present procedures on an XCell SureLock Mini-Cell system with NuPAGE precast gels (Thermo Scientific). Alternative systems and gels from other manufacturers can achieve similar results.
Assemble the XCell SureLock Mini-Cell system with 10- or 15-well NuPAGE 4%–12% Bis-Tris mini gels and MOPS SDS running buffer.
Load sequentially 5 μL protein makers, 15 μL of each pre-IP lysate samples (M45, WT, and F663S), 15 μL of each HA-IP samples (M45, WT, and F663S), or 15 μL of each occludin-IP samples (M45, WT, and F663S), and 5 μL protein makers.
Start electrophoresis with a constant voltage of 200 V. Stop when the dye front is around 1 cm away from the base of the gel.
Note: The electrophoresis time is about 60 min.
Transfer proteins to PVDF membrane.
We describe a procedure on a Trans-Blot Turbo transfer system with Trans-Blot Turbo Mini 0.2 μm PVDF Transfer Pack that includes filter paper, buffer, 0.2 μm PVDF membrane (Bio-Rad). Alternative systems and reagents can achieve similar results.
Carefully remove the precast gel from the XCell SureLock Mini-Cell system.

Assemble the transfer blot “sandwich” in the cassette of the Trans-Blot Turbo transfer system using a Trans-Blot Turbo Mini 0.2 μm PVDF Transfer Pack.
Start transferring proteins to PVDF membrane at a constant 25 V for 30 min.
Conduct western immunoblotting.
Remove the PVDF membrane from the cassette.
Block the membrane with TBST containing 5% skim milk with agitation for 1 h at room temperature (25°C).
Wash the membrane in TBST 3 times with agitation for 5 min each.
Cut the membrane according to the molecular weight of target proteins. Incubate the membrane slices in 5 mL of respective primary antibody diluted in TBST containing 5% BSA overnight (16–20 h) at 4°C on a low-speed shaker.
Note: We cut the membrane at 75 kDa. The top membrane slice is incubated with HA-antibody to detect GPR110. The bottom membrane slice is incubated with occludin antibody.
Remove the primary antibody solution. Wash the membrane in TBST 3 times with agitation for 5 min each.
Incubate the membranes in peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody diluted in TBST containing 5% milk with agitation for 1 h at room temperature (25°C).
Remove the secondary antibody solution. Wash the membrane in TBST 3 times with agitation for 5 min each.
Incubate the membrane with ECL Substrate reagent for 5 min.
Visualize the protein bands using an imager.
Optional: Step g is an optional step for detecting β-actin, a housekeeping protein as loading control.
Reprobe the bottom membrane with β-actin.
Wash the membrane with TBST for 5 min.
Incubate the membrane in 20 mL of stripping buffer (Restore western blot stripping buffer, Thermo Scientific) with agitation for 15 min at room temperature (25°C).
Wash the membrane in TBST 3 times with agitation for 5 min each.

Block the membrane with TBST containing 5% skim milk with agitation for 30 min at room temperature (25°C).
Wash the membrane in TBST 3 times with agitation for 5 min each.
Incubate the membrane in 5 mL of β-actin antibody diluted in TBST containing 5% BSA overnight (16–20 h) at 4°C on a low-speed shaker.
Proceed to Steps fv-ix.
Data analysis.
Confirm occludin is co-immunoprecipitated with WT GPR110, but not with the M45 control.
Confirm WT GPR110 is co-immunoprecipitated with occludin, but not with the M45.
Quantify band intensity using appropriate software.
Calculate the ratio of co-immunoprecipitated occludin over the bait GPR110. Compare the ratio of WT GPR110 transfected-sample with that of the F663S-transfected sample.
Calculate the ratio of co-immunoprecipitated GPR110 over the bait occludin. Compare the ratio of WT GPR110 transfected-sample with that of the F663S-transfected sample.
Note: The ratio of the prey protein over the bait protein is expected to decrease for the F663S-transfected sample compared to the WT sample. The data from pre-IP lysate is used for normalization of the bait protein.
